page.lettertext:
fol.285r
Belgia 1592 31 August To my L Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. Heere are letters
from
e campe, by w
ch
we are advertised, that
the army of
e Enemie is come neere unto
Count
Maurice
, w
t
in lesse then half a legue, and lodged
very strongly, expecting further forces. The
Count therupon doth solicit by his letters, w
ch
he
sendes abroad to every Province, to be presently
assisted w
t
all
e aide
at can be spared. It
is not muche
at they can spare, but w
at
the contrey
shall be able, will be sent w
t
all diligence: aswel
to give him greater strength, if
e Enemie should
charge him, as to assure
e frontier places against
any enterprise. In effect it is thought
at there
are, or will be shortly, accounting horse and foote,
between ten and eleven thousand. The
states
at are heere, and likewise
e
Councel
at
continueth at
Swol
, w
ch
is distant from
e campe
about two daies jorney, are greatly troubled w
t
this mater:
e more a great deale, for
at Count
Maurice in this siege, hath taken contrary courses
to their special directions. The chiefetaines
of
e Enemie are men of fame and
great
know
e
experience,
that,
Count Hohenlo
excepted, we have none of like
account: so as mst men are persuaded,
at
as-
well
both
for their credit,
a
d for
e
reskuing of
Coevoerden
,
they will not part from o
r
campe w
t
out geving
some attempt, to trie
e courage and valo
r
and
conduct of Count Maurice. I am buisied
at this present to procure a pard
o
of
e states,
for
e 33 Englishe sea men, w
ch
are in prison for
piracie in
Enchusen
and
Amsterdam
, and for whome
yo
r
L. of late hath written unto me. Howe I
fol.285v
To
[.]
Au
g
31 by Garrels
o
have proceeded, and w
at
I have obtened, I should
but trouble yow w
t
rehersal, not having yet brought
it to a full resolution. They were all of them
condemned, before yo
r
letter came unto me, but yet
I hope this intercession will enlarge
e greater mul-
titude. At this v ery instant,
a
d
e wri-
ting heerof, we have
certaine intelligence
letters
from
e
Campe,
at
e 28 of this moneth, about 4 of the
clocke in
e morning, the Enemie came upon us w
t
a wonderfull furie, and
entred
brake into
o
r
trenches
with a
but was valiantly replused, w
t
e slaughter of
many spaniardes, w
ch
had
e vantgard of
e troupes,
and w
t
e losse
on o
r
side
am
o
g o
r
of one onely man.
Count William
in
e c
o
flict, receaved some hurt,
but w
t
out any danger: and
e Enemie is reti-
red, but whether it is not signified. For the
l
res
were written by some
at were
then
p
nt
,
and for hast of sending first omitted many
ticularities: w
ch
I thought notw
t
standing would
deserve to be reported in suche sort as we have
it.
And so &c.
